danger_zone.reset_settings_desc: Use this option if you want to reset your settings to default values. This will not delete your solves or sessions, only your local settings.

danger_zone.delete_account_warning: Be careful here. If you click the button below, you will delete your entire account. All your solves, session data, statistics, etc. will be permanently deleted. Proceed with caution.

trainer.export_desc: Download all your algorithms and statistics as a JSON file to your device. You can keep this file as a backup or transfer it to another device.
trainer.import_desc: Select a previously exported JSON file to restore your algorithms. Your current data will be replaced with the data in the file.

pll.title: Permutation of Last Layer
pll.desc:
PLL is the final stage of the CFOP method, where all last layer pieces are moved to their correct positions while the top face color remains solved. At this point, the cross, F2L, and OLL are complete ‚Äî you just need to shuffle pieces into their home positions. The set includes 21 algorithms, each named after a letter: Aa, Ab, E, F, Ga, Gb, Gc, Gd, H, Ja, Jb, Na, Nb, Ra, Rb, T, Ua, Ub, V, Y, and Z. Many speedcubers choose to learn PLL before full OLL since it has fewer cases and provides an immediate, noticeable improvement in solve times.

Recognition is one of the most important skills for fast PLL execution. Most cubers identify cases by looking for headlights (two stickers of the same color side by side on one face) and blocks (connected solved pairs). For example, the T perm has a 1x1x3 block on the front and headlights on the left, while the Y perm has no blocks at all. With practice, you can recognize any PLL case from just two faces in under a second.

Before and after executing a PLL algorithm, you will often need to perform AUF (Adjust U Face) ‚Äî a simple U, U', or U2 turn to align the last layer with the rest of the cube. Efficient AUF prediction, where you determine the final adjustment during the algorithm itself, is a key skill that separates sub-15 solvers from faster cubers. The fastest PLL cases are typically the U perms and H perm, while the N perms and G perms tend to be the slowest due to their length and grip changes.

oll.title: Orientation of Last Layer
oll.desc:
OLL is the third stage of CFOP. The goal is to orient every piece on the last layer so the top face becomes one solid color ‚Äî for example, making the entire yellow face if you solve white first. There are 57 distinct cases in total, and they are commonly grouped by how many edges are already oriented: cross cases (all 4 edges oriented, leaving only corners to fix), shape cases like L, T, P, and W (2 edges oriented), and dot cases (0 edges oriented). If you already know 2-Look OLL, about 9-10 of those 57 are covered.

The difficulty and speed of OLL cases vary significantly by group. Cross cases are generally the fastest because they tend to be short algorithms with good fingertricks. Shape cases (L, T, P, W) form the middle ground ‚Äî they are recognizable by the distinctive patterns their oriented edges create. Dot cases, where no edges are oriented, tend to be the slowest and hardest to both recognize and execute, since the algorithms are typically longer and involve more grip changes.

Many OLL algorithms are mirrors or inverses of each other, which greatly helps with memorization. A common learning strategy is to start with the cross cases (since you already get the cross from 2-Look OLL), then learn the shape cases grouped by type, and finally tackle the dot cases last. Some speedcubers choose to never learn certain rare dot cases and instead use 2-Look for those specific situations, since the time investment may not be worth the marginal gain.

f2l.title: First Two Layers
f2l.desc:
F2L is the second stage of CFOP, where you pair a corner with its matching edge and insert them into the correct slot simultaneously. This is significantly faster than solving the cross, corners, and second layer edges as separate steps. There are 41 basic cases plus their mirrors, covering every possible configuration of a corner-edge pair relative to its target slot. Learning F2L intuitively before memorizing algorithms is strongly recommended ‚Äî understanding why pieces move where they do makes it much easier to handle cases you have not drilled yet.

Lookahead is the single most important skill for F2L speed. While inserting one pair, you should already be tracking the pieces of your next pair so there is no pause between insertions. This is what separates sub-20 solvers from sub-15 and below. Minimizing cube rotations is equally critical: every full cube rotation costs time and disrupts your lookahead flow. Top solvers aim to complete most pairs using only R, U, and F moves without rotating the cube at all.

The algorithms provided here are speed-optimized solutions that prioritize fingertrick efficiency and low move count. However, many cubers find that their intuitive solutions are nearly as fast for common cases. The biggest gains from algorithmic F2L come in tricky cases ‚Äî such as when the corner is twisted in the slot or when both pieces are stuck in the wrong slot. Focus your algorithm study on these difficult cases rather than trying to memorize all 41+ solutions at once.

2_look_pll.title: 2-Look PLL
2_look_pll.desc:
2-Look PLL is a beginner-friendly approach to the PLL step that breaks permutation into two manageable stages. In the first step, you permute the corners using algorithms like the A perm (Aa or Ab) for adjacent corner swaps and the E perm for diagonal corner swaps. In the second step, you permute the edges using the U perms (Ua and Ub) for 3-edge cycles, the H perm for swapping two opposite edge pairs, and the Z perm for swapping two adjacent edge pairs.

With only about 6 algorithms total, 2-Look PLL is far more approachable than the full 21-algorithm PLL set. It is the recommended starting point for anyone transitioning from the beginner method to CFOP. While it does add one extra look and algorithm execution compared to 1-Look PLL, the time difference is small ‚Äî typically only 1-2 seconds ‚Äî and the reduced learning burden lets you focus on improving other areas of your solve like F2L efficiency and lookahead.

Once you are comfortable with 2-Look PLL, the natural progression is to learn the remaining full PLL algorithms one or two at a time. Many cubers start by adding the T perm and J perms since they appear frequently and have easy fingertricks.

2_look_oll.title: 2-Look OLL
2_look_oll.desc:
2-Look OLL is a simplified approach to OLL that breaks the orientation step into two stages. In the first step, you orient the edges to form a yellow cross on top ‚Äî there are only 3 possible edge patterns (dot, L-shape, and line) plus the already-solved cross. In the second step, you orient the corners using algorithms like Sune, Anti-Sune, and their variations. This gives you roughly 9-10 algorithms to learn in total.

This approach is much easier to learn than the full 57-algorithm OLL set and is the recommended starting point for any cuber moving beyond the beginner method. The edge orientation step uses a single algorithm (F R U R' U' F') applied one or two times depending on the case, while the corner orientation step introduces Sune (R U R' U R U2 R') and its variants. Together, these cover every possible OLL situation.

The main trade-off compared to full OLL is speed ‚Äî 2-Look OLL requires two algorithm executions and an extra recognition pause between them. However, the time difference is typically only 1-3 seconds per solve, which makes it an excellent investment for cubers averaging 30 seconds or more. Once your solves are consistently under 25 seconds, gradually replacing 2-Look cases with their single-algorithm full OLL equivalents is the natural next step.

coll.title: Corners of Last Layer
coll.desc:
COLL solves the corners of the last layer while preserving edge orientation, meaning it can only be applied when all four last layer edges are already oriented (you have a cross on top). There are 42 algorithms divided across 6 subsets based on the corner orientation pattern: S (Sune), AS (Anti-Sune), T, U, L, and H (also called Pi). Each subset corresponds to a different way the corner stickers can be arranged on the top face.

The main benefit of COLL is that it guarantees a PLL case with already-solved corners. This means you will only ever get edge-only PLLs: the U perms (Ua, Ub), H perm, Z perm, or a complete PLL skip. You have a 1/12 chance of skipping PLL entirely, and the remaining cases are among the fastest PLLs to execute. This effectively eliminates slow cases like the G perms, N perms, and other multi-swap PLLs from your solves.

COLL is also a natural stepping stone toward learning ZBLL. Every COLL case is a subset of ZBLL ‚Äî once you know COLL, you already have 42 of the 493 ZBLL algorithms memorized. Many competitive cubers use COLL selectively, applying it only when they recognize a favorable OLL case that leads to a cross on top, and defaulting to standard OLL otherwise. This selective approach gives most of the benefit with a fraction of the learning effort.

ollcp.title: OLL + Corner Permutation
ollcp.desc:
OLLCP handles orientation of the last layer and corner permutation in a single step. Instead of just making the top face one color (like standard OLL), OLLCP also places the corners into their correct positions simultaneously. This means that after OLLCP, you are guaranteed an edge-only PLL ‚Äî the same benefit as COLL, but applied to every OLL case, not just the ones with oriented edges.

The full OLLCP set contains approximately 331 algorithms, making it one of the largest algorithm sets in competitive cubing. Because of this massive size, most cubers do not learn the entire set. Instead, they selectively learn OLLCP algorithms for specific OLL cases where the payoff is highest ‚Äî particularly OLL cases that frequently lead to slow G perms or N perms when solved with standard OLL. This selective approach lets you get meaningful time savings without committing to hundreds of algorithms.

OLLCP is recommended only for advanced cubers who are already comfortable with full OLL and full PLL. It is primarily used in CFOP, but some Roux solvers also apply OLLCP concepts in specific situations. If you are considering learning OLLCP, a good starting strategy is to identify which 5-10 OLL cases give you the worst PLL outcomes and learn OLLCP alternatives for just those cases first.

zbll.title: Zborowski-Bruchem Last Layer
zbll.desc:
ZBLL solves the entire last layer ‚Äî both orientation and permutation of all corners and edges ‚Äî in a single algorithm, provided that all four edges are already oriented. This makes it ideal for methods where edge orientation is handled earlier in the solve, such as ZZ (which orients all edges during the first step) or CFOP with ZBLS/VHLS. The full set contains 493 algorithms divided across 7 subsets: T, U, L, H, Pi, S, and AS ‚Äî each named after the corner orientation pattern on top, mirroring the COLL subsets.

Learning full ZBLL is one of the largest commitments a speedcuber can make. Most cubers who pursue it spend 1-2 years to fully memorize and drill all 493 cases. The payoff is significant: you effectively reduce the last layer to a single algorithm execution, saving 2-4 seconds per solve compared to OLL+PLL. Recognition speed is critical ‚Äî you need to identify the exact case from 493 possibilities quickly, which requires extensive pattern recognition practice beyond just memorizing the algorithms.

The recommended learning order is to start with the T and U subsets (which have the most ergonomic algorithms), then move to L and H, and finish with Pi, S, and AS. Many competitive ZZ solvers learn ZBLL subsets gradually over months, using COLL+PLL as a fallback for unlearned cases. Even partial ZBLL knowledge provides measurable improvement, since each learned subset eliminates a class of two-step solves.

wvls.title: Winter Variation Last Slot
wvls.desc:
WVLS, also known as Winter Variation (WV), is an advanced last-slot technique for CFOP and ZZ solvers. It applies in a very specific situation: the last F2L corner-edge pair must already be paired together and ready to insert, and the last layer edges must already be oriented (forming a cross on top). When these conditions are met, WVLS modifies the insertion of the final pair to simultaneously orient the last layer corners ‚Äî effectively skipping OLL entirely and going straight to PLL.

There are 27 cases in total, making WVLS a relatively small algorithm set that provides a significant payoff. Since the prerequisite is a paired F2L pair with oriented edges, it naturally pairs well with ZZ (where edges are always oriented) and can also arise in CFOP solves when the OLL edges happen to be oriented during the last slot. The algorithms are generally short and fingertrick-friendly since they are based on modified R U insertions.

The main limitation of WVLS is that the pair must already be connected ‚Äî if the corner and edge are separated, you need to pair them first, which may disrupt the edge orientation. For cubers who want to handle unpaired situations as well, the broader VLS (Vandenbergh Last Slot) set covers those cases but at a much higher algorithm count. WVLS is an excellent return-on-investment algorithm set for cubers looking to add conditional OLL skips to their solves.

vhls.title: Vandenbergh-Harris Last Slot
vhls.desc:
VHLS solves the last F2L pair while simultaneously orienting all four last layer edges. It is specifically designed for cases where the F2L pair can be inserted in 3 moves or fewer, which keeps the total algorithm count to just 32 manageable cases. The key idea is that instead of simply inserting the pair normally, you adjust the insertion to also flip any misoriented edges on the last layer.

After completing VHLS, the last layer is guaranteed to have all edges oriented (a cross on top). This means only cross-type OLL cases remain, which dramatically increases your chances of favorable outcomes. The probability of a complete OLL skip jumps from the standard 1/216 to 1/27, and even when you do not skip OLL, the remaining cross cases are among the fastest and most ergonomic OLL algorithms.

VHLS pairs naturally with COLL: after VHLS gives you oriented edges, COLL can solve the corners while setting up for an edge-only PLL. This VHLS + COLL + EPLL pipeline is a popular intermediate approach for cubers who want better last-layer outcomes without committing to full ZBLL. The 3-move insertion limit keeps the set small and practical, though cubers seeking complete edge-orientation control during the last slot should look into the full ZBLS set.

zbls.title: Zborowski-Bruchem Last Slot
zbls.desc:
ZBLS, also known as EOLS (Edge Orientation Last Slot), inserts the final F2L corner-edge pair while simultaneously orienting all last layer edges. It is the first half of the ZB method ‚Äî after ZBLS ensures all edges are oriented, ZBLL can solve the entire last layer in a single algorithm. Together, ZBLS + ZBLL creates one of the most powerful two-step last layer approaches in speedcubing.

With approximately 302 algorithms, ZBLS is a significant learning investment. The cases cover every possible combination of last-slot pair position and last-layer edge orientation state. Unlike VHLS, which only handles pairs insertable in 3 moves or fewer, ZBLS covers all situations ‚Äî including cases where the pair is split, misoriented, or partially stuck in the wrong slot. This completeness is what makes it so large but also so powerful.

ZBLS is primarily used by ZZ method solvers (where edge orientation on the first two layers is already handled, leaving only last layer edges) and by advanced CFOP solvers who want to transition to a ZB-based last layer. The recommended approach is to learn the most common cases first and gradually expand coverage. Many cubers use ZBLS selectively ‚Äî applying it when they recognize a familiar case and falling back to normal F2L insertion + OLL for unlearned ones.

cmll.title: Corners of Last Layer (Roux)
cmll.desc:
CMLL is the third step of the Roux method. After building the two 1x2x3 blocks on the left and right sides, you solve all four last layer corners ‚Äî both their orientation and permutation ‚Äî in a single step. The key difference from COLL is that CMLL is free to disturb the M-slice (the middle layer), since the M-slice will be solved later during the Last Six Edges (L6E) step. This freedom allows CMLL algorithms to be shorter and more efficient than their COLL equivalents.

There are 42 algorithms divided across 8 subsets based on the corner orientation pattern: O (oriented), S (Sune), AS (Anti-Sune), T, U, L, H (also called Pi), and the solved case. Each subset groups cases by how the corner top-face stickers are arranged, making recognition systematic once you learn the patterns. The algorithms primarily use R, U, and F moves, keeping them fingertrick-friendly.

CMLL is a core requirement for competitive Roux solving ‚Äî there is no way to avoid it at higher levels. The 42 algorithms are very manageable compared to other advanced sets, and most Roux solvers learn full CMLL relatively early in their progression. For beginners just starting Roux, 2-Look CMLL provides a stepping stone, but transitioning to full CMLL should be a priority once you are comfortable with block building.

2_look_cmll.title: 2-Look CMLL
2_look_cmll.desc:
2-Look CMLL is a simplified version of CMLL designed for beginner and intermediate Roux solvers. After building the two 1x2x3 blocks, you solve the last layer corners in two steps: first orient all four corners so the top-face color is on top, then permute them into their correct positions. This requires approximately 9 algorithms total ‚Äî significantly fewer than the 42 needed for full CMLL.

The orientation step uses the same algorithms as 2-Look OLL corner orientation (Sune, Anti-Sune, and their variants), while the permutation step uses corner-swap algorithms similar to those found in PLL. If you already know 2-Look OLL from CFOP, you will find that many of these algorithms are familiar, making the transition to Roux smoother.

2-Look CMLL is sufficient for getting started with Roux and can carry you to sub-30 or even sub-25 times with good block building. However, full CMLL should be learned once you are comfortable with the method, as the time saved per solve adds up quickly. The good news is that with only 42 total cases, full CMLL is one of the smaller advanced algorithm sets ‚Äî most cubers can learn it in a few weeks of focused practice.

oh_cmll.title: One-Handed CMLL
oh_cmll.desc:
OH-CMLL covers the same 42 CMLL cases but uses different algorithms specifically optimized for one-handed (OH) solving. When solving with a single hand, many standard two-handed algorithms become awkward or impossible to execute smoothly, so OH-CMLL replaces them with alternatives that flow naturally with one-hand fingertricks. The algorithms generally avoid z and x rotations, which are difficult to perform with one hand, and favor R, U, and r moves that can be executed fluidly.

One-handed Roux is a popular event category, and CMLL is often the step where OH solvers gain or lose the most time. Since you only have one hand to work with, algorithm choice matters even more than in two-handed solving ‚Äî a bad fingertrick sequence can cost several seconds. The algorithms in this set prioritize smooth, continuous finger movements without regrips or awkward hand positions.

If you already know standard CMLL, transitioning to OH-CMLL involves relearning some cases with new algorithms while keeping others that already work well one-handed. Many cubers find that about half of their two-handed CMLL algorithms transfer directly to OH, while the other half need replacements. Practice these new algorithms slowly at first, focusing on clean fingertricks, before pushing for speed.

l6e_eo.title: Last Six Edges ‚Äî Edge Orientation
l6e_eo.desc:
L6E Edge Orientation is the first substep (step 4a) of the Last Six Edges stage in the Roux method. After CMLL solves the corners, six edges remain unsolved: four on the U layer and two in the M-slice (UL and UR positions, plus the M-slice edges). The goal of this step is to orient all six edges so they can be solved using only M and U moves in subsequent steps. This is solved entirely with M and U moves.

There are 6 total cases for edge orientation. Four of them are called arrow cases because the oriented edges form an arrow-like pattern pointing in a direction, and the remaining two are non-arrow cases. Arrow cases are generally easier to recognize and solve, while non-arrow cases require an extra setup move. With only 6 cases, this step can be learned very quickly ‚Äî most cubers memorize all cases within a single practice session.

Edge orientation recognition becomes intuitive with practice. You learn to see which edges are 'good' (can be solved with M/U moves) and which are 'bad' (need to be flipped). Speed in this step comes from instant recognition rather than algorithm execution speed, since the solutions are very short. Mastering EO recognition is also the foundation for the more advanced EOLR technique.

l6e_eolr.title: Edge Orientation + Left/Right
l6e_eolr.desc:
EOLR is an advanced Roux technique that combines edge orientation (step 4a) with placing the UL and UR edges (step 4b) into a single step. Instead of first orienting all edges and then separately positioning UL/UR, EOLR handles both simultaneously. The goal is to orient all six remaining edges while also ensuring the UL and UR edges end up on the bottom layer, ready to be inserted with a simple M2 move.

EOLR is largely intuitive rather than algorithmic, which is part of what makes it appealing. Once you understand how M and U moves affect edge orientation and position, you can plan both outcomes together. The technique builds directly on your EO recognition skills ‚Äî instead of just seeing which edges need flipping, you also track where UL and UR are and choose your EO solution to place them favorably. This saves the separate step 4b entirely, reducing LSE to just two steps: EOLR and then the final M-slice edges.

Mastering EOLR is one of the key milestones for competitive Roux solvers. It typically saves 1-2 seconds per solve compared to solving EO and LR separately, and it makes the LSE phase feel much more fluid. The learning curve is moderate ‚Äî it requires developing a new way of seeing the cube during LSE rather than memorizing hundreds of algorithms. Most cubers develop EOLR skill gradually through deliberate slow solves where they consciously plan both EO and LR outcomes before executing.

2x2_cll.title: 2x2 Corners of Last Layer
2x2_cll.desc:
CLL is used to solve the last layer of a 2x2 cube in a single step, rather than the two-step approach used in beginner methods (orient then permute). It requires the first layer to be fully solved ‚Äî all four bottom-layer corners must be correctly positioned and oriented before applying a CLL algorithm. There are 42 cases in total, covering every possible arrangement of the four top-layer corners.

CLL is the standard intermediate algorithm set for 2x2 solvers. The method flow is straightforward: solve the first layer, then apply one CLL algorithm to solve everything else. Because the 2x2 has no edges or centers, CLL alone is sufficient to complete the entire cube once the first layer is done. The algorithms are generally short (8-12 moves) and most have excellent fingertricks.

Once you learn CLL, the natural next step is EG-1 and EG-2. The EG family extends the concept: instead of requiring a fully solved first layer, you only need one solved face (regardless of whether the bottom corners are permuted correctly). CLL covers the case where the first layer happens to be fully solved (1/6 probability), while EG-1 and EG-2 handle the remaining states. This progression lets you skip the time-consuming step of permuting first-layer corners entirely.

2x2_eg1.title: 2x2 EG-1
2x2_eg1.desc:
EG-1 is the algorithm set that handles the most common first-layer state in 2x2 solving: the adjacent swap. After solving one face (not a full layer ‚Äî just getting all four stickers of one color on the bottom), the four bottom corners can be in one of three permutation states: fully solved (CLL), adjacent swap (EG-1), or diagonal swap (EG-2). The adjacent swap occurs with 4/6 probability, making EG-1 the most frequently used set in the EG family.

There are 29 EG-1 cases. Each algorithm simultaneously solves the adjacent corner swap on the bottom layer and all four top-layer corners in a single step. This is what makes EG so powerful ‚Äî instead of first permuting the bottom corners (which costs extra moves and time) and then applying CLL, you solve everything at once after just building a face. The algorithms are slightly longer than CLL on average but the time saved by skipping first-layer permutation more than compensates.

Learning EG-1 is the highest-impact upgrade after CLL because of its high probability. Together, CLL and EG-1 cover 5/6 of all possible bottom-layer states, meaning you will only need EG-2 in 1 out of every 6 solves. Many competitive 2x2 solvers learn CLL + EG-1 first and use a fallback approach for the rare diagonal swap cases while they work on learning EG-2.

2x2_eg2.title: 2x2 EG-2
2x2_eg2.desc:
EG-2 handles the diagonal swap state of the first layer ‚Äî where two diagonally opposite bottom corners need to be swapped. This is the least common of the three EG states, occurring with only 1/6 probability. There are 29 cases, each solving the diagonal bottom swap and all four top corners simultaneously.

EG-2 is typically the last set learned in the EG family because of its low frequency. From a pure time-saving perspective, CLL and EG-1 together cover 5/6 of solves, so EG-2 only affects roughly 1 in 6 solves. However, for competitive 2x2 solvers aiming for sub-3 or sub-2 averages, having a fast one-look solution for every possible state is essential ‚Äî falling back to a two-step approach for diagonal swaps costs valuable time in a puzzle where every fraction of a second matters.

With CLL, EG-1, and EG-2 fully learned, you have complete coverage of all possible 2x2 states after solving one face. This means the entire solve becomes just two steps: solve a face (typically planned in inspection), then apply one algorithm. This is the foundation of competitive 2x2 solving and is used by virtually all top-level solvers. The total algorithm count across all three sets is about 100, which is very manageable compared to 3x3 algorithm sets.

2x2_pbl.title: Permutation of Both Layers
2x2_pbl.desc:
PBL is the final step of the Ortega method for the 2x2 cube. The Ortega method has three steps: solve one face, orient the opposite face (so both top and bottom are solid colors), and then use PBL to permute both layers simultaneously so all sides are solved. Unlike the beginner method which requires solving a full first layer with correct corner positions, Ortega only needs the face colors to match ‚Äî the corners can be in any order.

There are only 6 PBL cases: no swap needed (skip), adjacent swap on top only, adjacent swap on bottom only, adjacent swap on both layers, diagonal swap on one layer, and diagonal swap on both layers. Two of these algorithms (similar to J Perm and Y Perm) may already be familiar from 3x3 solving, which means most cubers can learn the full PBL set in a single practice session.

PBL and the Ortega method are the recommended first step up from the beginner 2x2 method. With just 6 short algorithms, Ortega provides a significant speed improvement over layer-by-layer approaches because you never waste time positioning first-layer corners. Most cubers can achieve sub-5 averages with Ortega before moving on to the more algorithm-heavy CLL and EG methods.

4x4_pll_parity.title: 4x4 PLL Parity
4x4_pll_parity.desc:
PLL parity is one of the most frustrating aspects of 4x4 solving ‚Äî it occurs when the cube reaches a state that would be impossible on a 3x3, caused by the internal mechanics of even-layered cubes. PLL parity happens roughly every other solve (approximately 50% probability), so learning to handle it efficiently is essential for competitive 4x4 times. Note that PLL parity is separate from OLL parity, which is a different issue that affects edge orientation.

This set contains approximately 22 algorithms that combine standard PLL patterns with parity corrections, allowing you to fix parity and permute the last layer simultaneously in a single step. Without these combined algorithms, you would need to first execute a long parity algorithm and then solve PLL separately ‚Äî adding significant time to your solve. The integrated approach saves 2-4 seconds compared to the two-step method.

The algorithms tend to be longer than standard 3x3 PLL algorithms due to the parity correction component, and they often involve wide moves (Rw, Uw) that affect the inner layers. Practice these algorithms slowly at first, focusing on accuracy over speed, since a single misaligned inner layer can require you to redo significant portions of the solve. Most competitive 4x4 solvers prioritize learning the parity versions of the most common PLL cases first (U perms, T perm, etc.) and gradually expand their repertoire.

pyraminx_ll.title: Pyraminx Last Layer
pyraminx_ll.desc:
These algorithms solve the last layer of the Pyraminx using the Layer By Layer (LBL) method. The LBL approach has two main steps: solve the first layer (three edges and the bottom tip), then solve the last layer. This final step is also known as L3E (Last 3 Edges) in the Pyraminx community, since the tips can be trivially aligned at the end.

There are only 5 cases for the last layer, making this one of the simplest algorithm sets in all of cubing. The cases cover the different ways three edges can be misoriented or mispermuted. Most algorithms are short (4-8 moves) and easy to fingertrick. A complete beginner can learn all 5 cases in a single sitting, and the recognition is straightforward since there are so few possibilities.

LBL with these 5 algorithms is the standard beginner method for Pyraminx and can achieve times in the 8-15 second range with practice. For cubers wanting to go faster, L4E is the natural next step ‚Äî it changes the first step to creating a V-shape instead of a full layer, which is less restrictive and enables faster solutions.

pyraminx_l4e.title: Pyraminx Last 4 Edges
pyraminx_l4e.desc:
L4E (Last 4 Edges) is an advanced Pyraminx technique that improves upon the standard LBL method. The approach has two steps: first create a V-shape on the bottom face (solving two of the three bottom edges instead of all three), then solve the remaining four edges in a single step. There are 12 cases for the second step, covering all possible arrangements of the four unsolved edges.

The key advantage of L4E over LBL is that forming a V-shape is significantly less restrictive than solving a complete first layer. When you only need two bottom edges correct instead of three, you have more freedom in how you build the V ‚Äî this means fewer moves, less searching for pieces, and faster first-step execution. The trade-off is that the second step has more cases (12 vs. 5) and some algorithms are slightly longer, but the net result is faster solves.

L4E is the method used by most competitive Pyraminx solvers achieving sub-5 averages. Combined with good tip alignment (which can be planned during inspection) and efficient V-building, L4E enables times that are significantly faster than what LBL can achieve. The 12 algorithms are manageable to learn in a few practice sessions, making L4E an excellent investment for any Pyraminx solver looking to move beyond the beginner method.

sarah_intermediate.title: Sarah's Intermediate (Skewb)
sarah_intermediate.desc:
Sarah's Intermediate is a skewb method designed as a step up from the beginner method. With only 10 cases to learn, it offers a low-effort way to significantly improve your skewb times. The method has three distinct steps: solve one face, solve the opposite face, and then solve the remaining centers.

The second step ‚Äî solving the opposite face ‚Äî is where the algorithm knowledge comes in. The cases are solved using combinations of two fundamental move sequences: the sledgehammer (R' F R F') and the hedgeslammer (F R' F' R). These two triggers are the building blocks of virtually all skewb algorithms, so mastering them with fast fingertricks pays dividends across all skewb methods. The 10 cases cover every possible state of the opposite face given a solved first face.

Sarah's Intermediate is the recommended method for cubers who want to be competitive at skewb without investing in a large algorithm set. It can achieve sub-6 averages with good recognition and fingertricks, which is fast enough for most cubers. For those wanting to push further into sub-4 or sub-3 territory, Sarah's Advanced reduces the solve to just two steps but requires learning 134 cases ‚Äî a much larger commitment.

sarah_advanced.title: Sarah's Advanced (Skewb)
sarah_advanced.desc:
Sarah's Advanced is the primary competitive skewb method used by top solvers worldwide. It reduces the entire solve to just two steps: solve one face (usually planned entirely during inspection), then solve everything else ‚Äî the opposite face and all four remaining centers ‚Äî in a single step. This two-step approach eliminates the separate center-solving step of Sarah's Intermediate, saving significant time.

There are 134 cases for the second step, making this a substantial algorithm set. Most solutions are built from combinations of sledgehammers (R' F R F') and hedgeslammers (F R' F' R), which means the algorithms share common finger patterns and feel similar once you have drilled the fundamental triggers. Recognition is based on the positions and orientations of the unsolved corners and centers relative to the solved face.

Sarah's Advanced is necessary for achieving sub-3 averages and is used by virtually all podium-level skewb competitors. The 134 algorithms may seem daunting, but the shared structure of sledgehammer/hedgeslammer combinations makes them easier to learn than 134 completely unrelated algorithms would be. A good strategy is to learn the cases grouped by first-face color, starting with the most common configurations. Combined with full first-face planning during the 15-second inspection period, this method enables one-look solves that can be executed in under 2 seconds.

sq1_cube_shape.title: Square-1 Cube Shape
sq1_cube_shape.desc:
Cube Shape is always the first step in solving a Square-1, regardless of which method you use. The objective is to transform the puzzle from its scrambled, non-cubic shape back into a proper cube form. Until the puzzle is in cube shape, you cannot apply standard algorithms for corner and edge permutation since the layers do not turn in predictable ways.

The cases are organized by shape groups based on the geometric forms the top and bottom layers create ‚Äî names like kite, scallop, square, barrel, shield, and mushroom describe the silhouette of each layer. There are approximately 90 distinct shape combinations, but many share the same algorithm or algorithm group, so the actual number of solutions you need to learn is much smaller. Most cubers learn cube shape by grouping cases: first identify the top and bottom shapes, then apply the known sequence to reach cube form.

Cube shape is widely considered the most challenging step for Square-1 beginners because the puzzle does not behave like a standard twisty puzzle in its non-cubic state. However, with practice, recognition becomes fast and many shapes can be solved in just 2-4 slice moves. Advanced solvers plan cube shape partially or fully during inspection, and some also use CSP (Cubeshape Parity) techniques to detect and fix parity during this step rather than dealing with it later.

sq1_cp.title: Square-1 Corner Permutation
sq1_cp.desc:
Corner Permutation (CP) is performed after Cube Shape and Corner Orientation are complete. The goal of this step is to place all eight corners into their correct positions on the top and bottom layers. There are 6 main cases, defined by the relationship between the top and bottom corner permutation states: adjacent-adjacent (adj-adj), adjacent-opposite (adj-opp), opposite-adjacent (opp-adj), and their variants.

Recognition involves identifying whether each layer has an adjacent swap (two neighboring corners need to swap), an opposite swap (two diagonal corners need to swap), or is already solved. The combination of the top and bottom states determines which CP algorithm to use. The algorithms are short and efficient, making CP one of the faster steps in a Square-1 solve.

CP is a critical step because it determines how the rest of the solve flows. Getting clean, fast CP execution with instant recognition of the 6 cases is essential for competitive Square-1 times. Many solvers practice CP recognition by drilling it as an isolated step until they can identify any case within a fraction of a second.

sq1_csp.title: Square-1 Cubeshape Parity
sq1_csp.desc:
CSP (Cubeshape Parity) is an advanced Square-1 technique that addresses parity errors during the Cube Shape step itself, rather than dealing with them later in the solve. Parity on the Square-1 is a unique issue ‚Äî roughly half of all scrambles have odd parity, which means a standard solve sequence will leave you one swap away from solved at the end. CSP fixes this upfront by incorporating a parity correction into the cubeshape algorithms.

The key advantage of CSP is that parity detection can happen during the 15-second inspection period, which does not count toward your solve time. By examining the positions of specific pieces during inspection, you can determine whether the scramble has odd or even parity. If odd parity is detected, you use a different cubeshape algorithm that simultaneously restores the cube shape and fixes parity. This eliminates the need for a separate, time-consuming parity algorithm later in the solve.

CSP is considered an advanced technique because it requires the ability to detect parity quickly during inspection and to know alternate cubeshape solutions for parity cases. However, for competitive Square-1 solvers, the time saved is substantial ‚Äî parity algorithms applied later in the solve typically cost 2-4 seconds, and eliminating them makes a significant difference in averages. Most top Square-1 solvers use CSP or a similar parity-during-cubeshape approach.

sq1_eo.title: Square-1 Edge Orientation
sq1_eo.desc:
Edge Orientation (EO) on the Square-1 comes after Cube Shape and Corner Orientation steps are complete. The goal is to orient all edges so that each edge's top or bottom sticker matches its respective layer color. After completing EO along with corner orientation, the top and bottom faces should be fully solved with correct colors ‚Äî only the side colors of edges may still be wrong, which is handled in the permutation steps.

There are 5 basic EO cases. Each case is defined by how many and which edges are misoriented. The algorithms are relatively short and use slice moves (the / notation unique to Square-1) to flip edge orientations without disturbing the already-solved corners. Recognition is straightforward since you are simply looking at the top and bottom faces for edges whose colors do not match.

EO is a quick step in most solves but accurate recognition is important ‚Äî misidentifying an EO case leads to incorrect edge orientations that compound problems in later steps. Practice recognizing which edges are flipped quickly, and drill the 5 algorithms until they are automatic.

sq1_ep.title: Square-1 Edge Permutation
sq1_ep.desc:
Edge Permutation (EP) is the final step of the Square-1 solve, where all edges are moved to their correct positions. At this point, the top and bottom face colors are correct and the corners are all in place ‚Äî only the edges need to be shuffled into their home positions. There are 4 basic EP cases in the standard (non-parity) state.

When parity is present (if it was not fixed during cubeshape using CSP), additional EP parity variants exist that require modified algorithms. These parity EP cases effectively double the case count, which is why many competitive solvers prefer to handle parity earlier via CSP rather than dealing with it during EP. The parity versions of EP algorithms are typically longer and less ergonomic.

EP recognition involves identifying which edges need to swap on the top and bottom layers ‚Äî similar to PLL recognition on a 3x3 but with the unique Square-1 notation. Clean, fast EP execution is the final piece of a competitive Square-1 solve, and since it is the last step, there is no recovery from mistakes. Practice both the standard and parity variants until they are consistent and accurate.

sq1_obl.title: Square-1 Orient Both Layers
sq1_obl.desc:
OBL (Orient Both Layers) is an advanced Square-1 technique that orients both corners and edges of the top and bottom layers simultaneously in a single step. In the standard approach, corner orientation (CO) and edge orientation (EO) are handled as separate steps ‚Äî OBL combines them, saving one full step and the recognition pause between them. There are approximately 17 cases to learn.

The trade-off is clear: more algorithms in exchange for fewer steps. The 17 OBL cases cover every combination of CO and EO states, and many of the algorithms are longer than their individual CO or EO counterparts since they handle both orientations at once. Recognition also requires evaluating both corner and edge orientations simultaneously, which takes practice to do quickly.

OBL is recommended for Square-1 solvers who have already mastered the standard step-by-step approach and are looking for the next level of optimization. The time savings come not just from the shorter algorithm sequence but also from eliminating the pause between CO and EO recognition. For competitive solvers aiming for sub-10 averages, OBL is one of several advanced techniques that contribute to shaving off those critical seconds.

appearance.timer_modules_desc: Change the number of modules shown on the timer page. Note that this is the *maximum* number of modules shown (based on your window size).
appearance.timer_layout_desc: Change the appearance of your timer. If you have a smaller screen, you may want to put modules to the left or right.
appearance.timer_background_desc: Change the background color or image of the timer.
appearance.timer_font_desc: The font of the large timer you see on the timer page
appearance.timer_font_size_desc: The font size of the large time you see on the timer page
appearance.scramble_font_size_desc: The font size of the scramble you see on the timer page
appearance.smart_cube_size_desc: Adjust the size of the smart cube on the homepage.

timer_settings.decimal_points_desc: How many decimal points to show on the timer page
timer_settings.input_type_desc: Choose between using your keyboard (spacebar), StackMat, or Smart Cube to start the timer.
timer_settings.freeze_time_desc: How many seconds to hold the spacebar before the timer starts.
timer_settings.cube_types_desc: Add custom cube types with or without scrambles
timer_settings.manage_cube_types_modal_desc: You can use custom scramble types for events not listed by default. For example 8x8 or Examinx or whatever comes to mind
timer_settings.space_with_smart_desc: Use the spacebar like normal cubes instead of detecting when a solve starts/ends by smart cube moves.
timer_settings.zero_out_time_desc: Instead of showing the time of your last solve, the timer updates to 0.00 after the solve.
timer_settings.require_period_desc: Turn this off if you want manually entered times to be automatically divided by 100
timer_settings.confirm_delete_solve_desc: Show a confirmation dialog before deleting a solve
timer_settings.confirm_delete_season_desc: Show a confirmation dialog before deleting all solves in the selected session
timer_settings.pb_confetti_desc: Show confetti when you beat your personal best
timer_settings.use_2d_scramble_visual_desc: Show 2D unfolded net for NxN cubes (2x2‚Äì7x7) instead of 3D
timer_settings.inspection_desc: Limit inspection time. Good for preparing for competitions.
timer_settings.play_sound_desc: Play an audio alert when 8 and 12 seconds have passed
timer_settings.inspection_auto_start_desc: Automatically start when inspection time runs out
timer_settings.stackmat_options_desc: These options will be used when your timer input type is set to StackMat
timer_settings.mic_access: Allow microphone access (StackMat's data transmission method)
timer_settings.stackmat_auto_inspection_desc: Automatically starts inspection time after the mat is reset.
timer_settings.stackmat_select: Select your StackMat device. Usually named "USB Audio Device"
timer_settings.stackmat_warning_subtitle: There is important information you should know about this feature.
timer_settings.stackmat_step1: Press the reset button on the mat after completing your solve
timer_settings.stackmat_step2: After the time you set (default 2 seconds), inspection starts automatically
timer_settings.stackmat_step3: If you start the timer within this time, inspection is cancelled
timer_settings.stackmat_limitation_text: If you cancel inspection with the ESC key, since no new signal comes from the mat, inspection won't start even if you press reset again. In this case, you need to start inspection from the keyboard (Space) or do a new solve.
timer_settings.stackmat_protocol_limitation: This limitation comes from the StackMat protocol and has no software solution.
timer_settings.stackmat_critical_warning: ‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL WARNING: Please DO NOT RESET on StackMat until the time has fully stopped after solving. This may cause the StackMat signal to synchronize incorrectly and may cause some errors in inspection time. We apologize for these protocol errors beyond our control.
timer_settings.use_space_with_smart_cube_desc: Use the spacebar like normal cubes instead of detecting when a solve starts/ends by smart cube moves.
timer_settings.zero_out_time_after_solve_desc: Instead of showing the time of your last solve, the timer updates to 0.00 after the solve.
timer_settings.auto_inspection_start_desc: Automatically starts inspection time after the mat is reset.
timer_settings.stackmat_warning_desc: There is important information you should know about this feature.
timer_settings.stackmat_warning_step1: Press the reset button on the mat after completing your solve
timer_settings.stackmat_warning_step2: After the time you set (default 2 seconds), inspection starts automatically
timer_settings.stackmat_warning_step3: If you start the timer within this time, inspection is cancelled
timer_settings.stackmat_warning_limitation_desc: If you cancel inspection with the ESC key, since no new signal comes from the mat, inspection won't start even if you press reset again. In this case, you need to start inspection from the keyboard (Space) or do a new solve.
timer_settings.stackmat_warning_protocol_note: This limitation comes from the StackMat protocol and has no software solution.
timer_settings.stackmat_warning_critical: ‚ö†Ô∏è CRITICAL WARNING: Please DO NOT RESET on StackMat until the time has fully stopped after solving. This may cause the StackMat signal to synchronize incorrectly and may cause some errors in inspection time. We apologize for these protocol errors beyond our control.

data_settings.force_reload_desc: If your data or settings are out of sync, you can force reload to re-sync with the database.
data_settings.export_data_desc: This data can serve as a backup for your solve and session data that can be imported later if needed.
data_settings.export_success: All solve and session data downloaded successfully.
data_settings.import_data_desc: Import data from csTimer or Zkt-Timer
data_settings.reset_settings_desc: Reset everything in settings to default values (except custom cube types)

data_settings.review_description: Make sure the numbers below are correct. Then import the data!

seo.home_title: Zkt-Timer | The Most Advanced Rubik's Cube Platform
seo.home_description: The most advanced Rubik's cube platform! Professional timer, live race rooms, smart cube support, detailed statistics and rankings. 3x3, 2x2, 4x4 and all WCA categories.
seo.timer_description: Professional Rubik's cube timer. Millisecond precision, WCA scramble algorithms, smart cube support and detailed performance analysis. The best timer for speedcubing.
seo.login_description: Log in to your ZKT Timer account. Save your solves, track your stats and take your place in the rankings.
seo.signup_description: Join the largest Rubik's cube community! Create a free account, save your solves and compete with other cubers.
seo.forgot_password_description: Reset your ZKT Timer account password. Set a new password with the link sent to your email.
seo.rooms_description: Race other cubers in real time! Create rooms with friends or join open rooms. The best platform for speedcubing competition.
seo.settings_description: Customize your timer settings, appearance and account preferences.
seo.user_profile_description: {{username}}'s Rubik's cube profile. Records, solve statistics and competition history.
seo.trainer_description: Learn F2L, OLL, PLL and more algorithms. Train with interactive 3D cube and improve your speed.
seo.stats_description: Analyze your Rubik's cube performance. Averages, best times, graphs and detailed statistics.
seo.solves_description: View all your Rubik's cube solves. Performance analysis with scramble, time and solve details.
seo.leaderboards_description: The fastest Rubik's cube solvers! Single and Average records, category-based rankings.
seo.demo_description: Try ZKT Timer for free! Explore timer features without creating an account.

features.timer_desc: A clean, distraction-free interface with millisecond precision. Full control with keyboard shortcuts.
features.stats_desc: Track your progress with charts. View your PBs, averages (AO5, AO12, AO100) and trends.
features.smart_cube_desc: Connect your Bluetooth-enabled cube and analyze your moves, TPS and turn errors.
features.rooms_desc: Create private rooms with friends or compete in public rooms. Live rankings and instant chat.

pro_page.title: Pro
pro_page.subtitle: Take your cubing to the next level with exclusive Pro features designed for serious speedcubers.
pro_page.feature_ai_coach_desc: Get personalized training plans and real-time analysis from our AI assistant that learns your solving patterns.
pro_page.feature_trainer_desc: Access specialized training modules for F2L, OLL, PLL and more with adaptive difficulty.
pro_page.feature_stats_desc: Deep dive into your performance with detailed charts, trend analysis, and solve breakdowns.
pro_page.feature_themes_desc: Personalize your timer with Pro-exclusive color themes and visual customization options.
pro_page.feature_support_desc: Get faster responses and direct access to the development team for feature requests.
pro_page.feature_early_access_desc: Be the first to try new features before they're released to the public.

report_user.title: Report {{username}}
report_user.description: If you believe this user has done something worth reporting, please write a short reason below and submit the report. We will review all reports fairly and take action if necessary.
report_user.success: Successfully reported {{username}}. We will take care of the rest
